The '''''Hrabianka Chronicle'''''{{efn|{{langx|uk|Літопис Граб'янки|Litopys Hrabjanky}}, or more fully, {{langx|uk|Літопис гадяцького полковника Григорія Граб'янки|Litopys hadjacjkoho polkovnyka Hryhorija Hrabjanky|Chronicle of the Hadiach Colonel Hryhorij Hrabjanka|label=none}}.}} is a [[Cossacks|Cossack]] [[chronicle]] from the second half of the 17th century to the early 18th century, compiled by ''[[polkovnyk]]'' ([[colonel]]) Hryhorii Hrabianka,{{efn|{{langx|uk|Григорій Граб'янка|Hryhorij Hrabjanka}}.}} who served in the [[Hadiach Regiment]] of the [[Cossack Hetmanate]].

The chronicle was first published anonymously under the title {{langx|uk|Лѣтописецъ Малыя Россіи|Litopysecj Malyja Rossij|The Chronicler of Little Russia|label=none}} by F. source_payload.html:
Plot

← Previous revision Revision as of 17:00, 8 February 2026
Line 69: Line 69:
Despondent over the departure of his only friend, Volodya commits suicide, his soul taking the form of an angel. In his new guise, Volodya comes to Lilya to watch over her and says being in heaven is really good but he wishes he'd stayed alive for longer. On Christmas Day, he transports Lilya to the roof of the apartment building where they lived and, deeply regretting having killed himself, gives her the world as a present, but Lilya rejects the gift because the world is cold and not that good. After an escape attempt, Lilya is violently beaten by her pimp, but she manages her escape when he forgets to lock the door to the apartment he imprisoned her in. Lilya panics when she sees a policewoman pull up outside a gas station (Witek had lied to her that if she tried to escape, the police would deport her back to her country and his partners would find and kill her there) and runs through the streets of [[Malmö]] before stopping on a bridge and crying tears of exhaustion and defeat. With the story arriving full circle to the scene at the beginning of the film, Lilya ignores Volodya's angel as he begs her to stop and jumps from the bridge overpass to her death.
Despondent over the departure of his only friend, Volodya commits suicide, his soul taking the form of an angel. In his new guise, Volodya comes to Lilya to watch over her and says being in heaven is really good but he wishes he'd stayed alive for longer. On Christmas Day, he transports Lilya to the roof of the apartment building where they lived and, deeply regretting having killed himself, gives her the world as a present, but Lilya rejects the gift because the world is cold and not that good. After an escape attempt, Lilya is violently beaten by her pimp, but she manages her escape when he forgets to lock the door to the apartment he imprisoned her in. Lilya panics when she sees a policewoman pull up outside a gas station (Witek had lied to her that if she tried to escape, the police would deport her back to her country and his partners would find and kill her there) and runs through the streets of [[Malmö]] before stopping on a bridge and crying tears of exhaustion and defeat. With the story arriving full circle to the scene at the beginning of the film, Lilya ignores Volodya's angel as he begs her to stop and jumps from the bridge overpass to her death.


The film's conclusion presents two different endings. One version shows Lilya being sent back in time after killing herself to when she made the decision to go to Sweden with Andrei. However, this time she rejects Andrei's offer, and she and Volodya are shown to presumably live happier lives. In the final scene, Lilya and Volodya are both angels happily playing basketball on the roof of a tenement building.

'''Nokomis''' is a [[Neighborhoods of Minneapolis|defined community]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. It takes its name from [[Lake Nokomis]]. It comprises eleven smaller neighborhoods. Nokomis neighborhoods fall in [[Minneapolis City Council]] wards 8, 11, and 12,<ref>{{cite web |title=Find My Ward |url=https://www.minneapolismn.gov/government/city-council/find-my-ward/ |website=City of Minneapolis |access-date=19 April 2024}}</ref> currently represented by council members [[Andrea Jenkins]], [[Emily Koski]], and [[Aurin Chowdhury]], respectively.
'''Nokomis''' is a [[Neighborhoods of Minneapolis|defined community]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. It takes its name from [[Lake Nokomis]]. It comprises eleven smaller neighborhoods. Post-war operations

← Previous revision Revision as of 17:00, 8 February 2026
Line 116: Line 116:
At the end of 1919, Trumbull Steel purchased additional land on which to build,<ref>{{cite news|title=Short Trade Items|work=The Iron Age|date=January 1, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=115|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-01-01_105_1/page/114/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> and began construction of a {{convert|1100|ft|adj=on}} long,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Extensions|work=The Iron Age|date=September 2, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=573|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-09-02_106_10/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> {{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} wide building to house a new {{convert|9|in|cm|adj=on}} hot-rolled strip mill and a {{convert|1200|ft|adj=on}} long,{{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} wide building to house a new {{convert|14|in|cm|adj=on}} hot-rolled strip mill.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> Both new buildings were parallel to its existing cold-rolling mill.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> The 14-inch mill was designed to handle steel bars of varying thickness up to {{convert|30|ft}} in length.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> The company also began work on extensions to its cold rolling mill building.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spend Millions at Steel Plant|work=The Plain Dealer|date=January 20, 1920|page=13|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Bonus Plan for Engineering Staffs|work=The Iron Age|date=January 29, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=338|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-01-29_105_5/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> The cold-rolling mill doubled its capacity by adding three {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on}} stands; three {{convert|12|in|cm|adj=on}} stands; a {{convert|10|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|16|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem, followed by two {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on}} combination stands;{{Efn|A "combination stand" combines a roughing stand and a guide for shaping (also called a "looping stand").<ref>{{cite book|author=American Society for Metals|title=Metals Handbook|location=Cleveland|publisher=American Society for Metals|date=1961|oclc=2369462|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Metals_Handbook/k24BJqLPhIYC?hl=en&gbpv=1&bsq=%22combination%20mill%22%20steel%20definition&dq=%22combination%20mill%22%20steel%20definition&printsec=frontcover|page=9}}</ref>}} a {{convert|20|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|24|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem; and a {{convert|12|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|20|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem (as an auxilliary stand).<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Expands|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 31, 1920|page=7}}</ref> The capacity of the annealing department was also doubled.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The changes allowed Trumbull Steel to add {{convert|150000|ST}} to its annual capacity,<ref name=feb1920additions>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Co.'s Additions|work=The Iron Age|date=February 26, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=611|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-02-26_105_9/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 1, 1920|page=13}}</ref> which was now {{convert|400000|ST}}.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The total cost of the improvements, which Trumbull Steel said it financed from earnings, was $3 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|3000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}).<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The new continuous hot mills garnered national attention in the mainstream financial and steel industry specialized press in September 1920,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 />{{Efn|The 9-inch hot rolling mill was completed in September 1920,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> while the 14-inch hot rolling mill was completed in early 1921.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill />}} but neither went into operation due to the depression that began in January 1920.
At the end of 1919, Trumbull Steel purchased additional land on which to build,<ref>{{cite news|title=Short Trade Items|work=The Iron Age|date=January 1, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=115|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-01-01_105_1/page/114/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> and began construction of a {{convert|1100|ft|adj=on}} long,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Extensions|work=The Iron Age|date=September 2, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=573|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-09-02_106_10/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> {{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} wide building to house a new {{convert|9|in|cm|adj=on}} hot-rolled strip mill and a {{convert|1200|ft|adj=on}} long,{{convert|100|ft|adj=on}} wide building to house a new {{convert|14|in|cm|adj=on}} hot-rolled strip mill.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> Both new buildings were parallel to its existing cold-rolling mill.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> The 14-inch mill was designed to handle steel bars of varying thickness up to {{convert|30|ft}} in length.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> The company also began work on extensions to its cold rolling mill building.<ref>{{cite news|title=Spend Millions at Steel Plant|work=The Plain Dealer|date=January 20, 1920|page=13|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Bonus Plan for Engineering Staffs|work=The Iron Age|date=January 29, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=338|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-01-29_105_5/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> The cold-rolling mill doubled its capacity by adding three {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on}} stands; three {{convert|12|in|cm|adj=on}} stands; a {{convert|10|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|16|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem, followed by two {{convert|8|in|cm|adj=on}} combination stands;{{Efn|A "combination stand" combines a roughing stand and a guide for shaping (also called a "looping stand").<ref>{{cite book|author=American Society for Metals|title=Metals Handbook|location=Cleveland|publisher=American Society for Metals|date=1961|oclc=2369462|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Metals_Handbook/k24BJqLPhIYC?hl=en&gbpv=1&bsq=%22combination%20mill%22%20steel%20definition&dq=%22combination%20mill%22%20steel%20definition&printsec=frontcover|page=9}}</ref>}} a {{convert|20|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|24|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem; and a {{convert|12|in|cm|adj=on}} and {{convert|20|in|cm|adj=on}} stand working in tandem (as an auxilliary stand).<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Expands|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=August 31, 1920|page=7}}</ref> The capacity of the annealing department was also doubled.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The changes allowed Trumbull Steel to add {{convert|150000|ST}} to its annual capacity,<ref name=feb1920additions>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Co.'s Additions|work=The Iron Age|date=February 26, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=611|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-02-26_105_9/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 1, 1920|page=13}}</ref> which was now {{convert|400000|ST}}.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The total cost of the improvements, which Trumbull Steel said it financed from earnings, was $3 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|3000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}).<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill /> The new continuous hot mills garnered national attention in the mainstream financial and steel industry specialized press in September 1920,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 />{{Efn|The 9-inch hot rolling mill was completed in September 1920,<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /> while the 14-inch hot rolling mill was completed in early 1921.<ref name=hugenewhotmill2 /><ref name=hugenewhotmill />}} but neither went into operation due to the depression that began in January 1920.


In April 1920, Trumbull Steel executives asked stockholders to approve a restructuring of its stock.<ref name=stocksplit>{{cite news|title=Wall Street Notes|work=Brooklyn Eagle|date=April 15, 1920|page=17|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stockholders to Vote on Capital Increase|work=New York Tribune|date=April 16, 1920|page=18}}</ref> Management wanted employees to become stockholders in the firm,<ref name=employeeparticip>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stock Issue|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=May 24, 1920|page=2}}</ref> but the high price of the common stock prevented most workers from buying it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stock for Employees|work=The Iron Age|date=March 18, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=812|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-03-18_105_12/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Cuts Par Value to Aid Investors|work=The Plain Dealer|date=August 17, 1920|page=17}}</ref><ref name=4for1b>{{cite news|title=Another Steel Dividend Coming|work=The Pittsburgh Press|date=July 21, 1920|page=6|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 23, 1920|page=7}}</ref> Under the restructuring proposal, the amount of common stock would increase by $11 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|11000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}) to $25 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|25000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}).<ref name=employeeparticip /><ref name=stocksplit>{{cite news|title=Wall Street Notes|work=Brooklyn Eagle|date=April 15, 1920|page=17|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stockholders to Vote on Capital Increase|work=New York Tribune|date=April 16, 1920|page=18}}</ref> Stockholders approved the restructuring on May 18.<ref name=cokeplant>{{cite news|title=Trumbull-Cliffs Furbace Co. Will Build By-Product Coke Plant|work=The Iron Age|date=May 27, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=1552|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-05-27_105_22/page/1552/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Finance|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=May 19, 1920|page=11}}</ref> Pursuant to the plan, Trumbull Steel declared a special 25% dividend on all common stock.<ref name=4for1a>{{cite news|title=Declare Stock Dividend|work=The Plain Dealer|date=July 9, 1920|page=22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Stock Dividend|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 9, 1920|page=1}}</ref>{{Efn|Executives had initially proposed a 75% dvidend on all common stock, to encourage stockholders to approve the split. The board of directors thought this execessive, and trimmed it to 25%.<ref name=4for1b />}} It then declared a 4-for-1 common [[stock split]].<ref name=4for1a /> Gross revenues in 1920 were $35,850,811 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|35850811|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), a 35% increase over 1919. Net earnings were $2.5 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|2500000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), a slight increase.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steet|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 3, 1921|page=3}}</ref>
In April 1920, Trumbull Steel executives asked stockholders to approve a restructuring of its stock.<ref name=stocksplit>{{cite news|title=Wall Street Notes|work=Brooklyn Eagle|date=April 15, 1920|page=17|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stockholders to Vote on Capital Increase|work=New York Tribune|date=April 16, 1920|page=18}}</ref> Management wanted employees to become stockholders in the firm,<ref name=employeeparticip>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stock Issue|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=May 24, 1920|page=2}}</ref> but the high price of the common stock prevented most workers from buying it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stock for Employees|work=The Iron Age|date=March 18, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=812|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-03-18_105_12/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Cuts Par Value to Aid Investors|work=The Plain Dealer|date=August 17, 1920|page=17}}</ref><ref name=4for1b>{{cite news|title=Another Steel Dividend Coming|work=The Pittsburgh Press|date=July 21, 1920|page=6|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 23, 1920|page=7}}</ref> Under the restructuring proposal, the amount of common stock would increase by $11 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|11000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}) to $25 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|25000000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}).<ref name=employeeparticip /><ref name=stocksplit>{{cite news|title=Wall Street Notes|work=Brooklyn Eagle|date=April 15, 1920|page=17|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Stockholders to Vote on Capital Increase|work=New York Tribune|date=April 16, 1920|page=18}}</ref> Stockholders approved the restructuring on May 18.<ref name=cokeplant>{{cite news|title=Trumbull-Cliffs Furbace Co. Will Build By-Product Coke Plant|work=The Iron Age|date=May 27, 1920|accessdate=January 14, 2026|page=1552|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1920-05-27_105_22/page/1552/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Finance|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=May 19, 1920|page=11}}</ref> Pursuant to the plan, Trumbull Steel set aside $2 million in par-value common stock for employees to purchase<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Raises Common By $11,000,000|work=Youngstown Vindicator|date=May 18, 1920 |page=1}}</ref> and declared a special 25% dividend on all common stock.<ref name=4for1a>{{cite news|title=Declare Stock Dividend|work=The Plain Dealer|date=July 9, 1920|page=22|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Trumbull Stock Dividend|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 9, 1920|page=1}}</ref>{{Efn|Executives had initially proposed a 75% dvidend on all common stock, to encourage stockholders to approve the split. The board of directors thought this execessive, and trimmed it to 25%.<ref name=4for1b />}} It then declared a 4-for-1 common [[stock split]],<ref name=4for1a /> reducing the common stock's part value to $25 from $100 so that it was more affordable for workers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Reach Employe, Trumbull Plan|work=Youngstown Vindicator|date=July 14, 1920|page=12}}</ref> Gross revenues in 1920 were $35,850,811 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|35850811|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), a 35% increase over 1919. Net earnings were $2.5 million ({{Inflation|US-GDP|2500000|1920|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), a slight increase.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steet|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 3, 1921|page=3}}</ref>


A [[Recession of 1920–1921|severe depression]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Haberler|first=Gottfried|title=Prosperity and Depression: A Theoretical Analysis of Cyclical Movements|location=New York|publisher=Taylor & Francis|date=2017|isbn=9781351496247|page=xiii|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Prosperity_and_Depression/GNwzDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22depression%20of%201920%22%20length&pg=PT15&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> occurred in the United States from January 1920 to July 1921.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parker|first=Randall E.|title=Reflections on the Great Depression|location=Cheltenham, UK|publisher=Edward Elgar|date=2002|isbn=9781840647457|page=2|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Reflections_on_the_Great_Depression/Y-g4AgAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=recession%201920%201921%20%2218%20months%22&pg=PA2&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> Trumbull Steel initiated no new expansion occurred at its mill, but did begin operation of its 9-inch mill in May.<ref name=millsinoperation>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Co.|work=The Iron Age|date=January 5, 1922|accessdate=January 15, 2026|page=116|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1922-01-05_109_1/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> Financial data for 1921 reflect the downturn in the economy: The firm had gross revenue of $12,851,000 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|12851000|1921|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), decline of 64.2%. Neat earnings were $200,000 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|200000|1921|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), down 92% from 1920. Rumors that Trumbull Steel might merge with one or more other independent steel manufacturers swirled all year. President Jonathan Warner told stockholders that an invitation to merge had been received during the year, but he had declined it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel's Net|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=February 8, 1922|page=12}}</ref> Despite the depression, Trumbull Steel employed more than 6,000 men in 1921.<ref>{{cite news|title=Business News of Today|work=The Buffalo News|date=February 28, 1922|page=23}}</ref>
A [[Recession of 1920–1921|severe depression]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Haberler|first=Gottfried|title=Prosperity and Depression: A Theoretical Analysis of Cyclical Movements|location=New York|publisher=Taylor & Francis|date=2017|isbn=9781351496247|page=xiii|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Prosperity_and_Depression/GNwzDwAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22depression%20of%201920%22%20length&pg=PT15&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> occurred in the United States from January 1920 to July 1921.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parker|first=Randall E.|title=Reflections on the Great Depression|location=Cheltenham, UK|publisher=Edward Elgar|date=2002|isbn=9781840647457|page=2|url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/Reflections_on_the_Great_Depression/Y-g4AgAAQBAJ?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=recession%201920%201921%20%2218%20months%22&pg=PA2&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> Trumbull Steel initiated no new expansion occurred at its mill, but did begin operation of its 9-inch mill in May.<ref name=millsinoperation>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel Co.|work=The Iron Age|date=January 5, 1922|accessdate=January 15, 2026|page=116|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1922-01-05_109_1/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> Financial data for 1921 reflect the downturn in the economy: The firm had gross revenue of $12,851,000 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|12851000|1921|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), decline of 64.2%. Neat earnings were $200,000 ({{Inflation|US-GDP|200000|1921|fmt=eq|r=-3}}), down 92% from 1920. Rumors that Trumbull Steel might merge with one or more other independent steel manufacturers swirled all year. President Jonathan Warner told stockholders that an invitation to merge had been received during the year, but he had declined it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Steel's Net|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=February 8, 1922|page=12}}</ref> Despite the depression, Trumbull Steel employed more than 6,000 men in 1921.<ref>{{cite news|title=Business News of Today|work=The Buffalo News|date=February 28, 1922|page=23}}</ref>
Line 129: Line 129:


At the end of 1924,<ref name=25savings>{{cite news|title=O.K.'s New Coal Fueling System|work=The Plain Dealer|date=January 18, 1925|page=40}}</ref> Trumbull Steel began using pulverized coal as a fuel for all of its mill and annealing furnaces.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pulverized Coal at Trumbull Steel Mills|work=The Iron Age|date=March 26, 1925|accessdate=January 16, 2026|page=885|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1925-03-26_115_13/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> The firm said it would save 25% a year on fuel costs.<ref name=25savings /> In February 1925, the company began installing new boilers and upgrading all its piping<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Improvements|work=The Cleveland Press|date=February 10, 1925|page=14}}</ref> and its common stock began trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]'s [[Curb trading|curb market]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Notes From Exchanges|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=February 17, 1925|page=18}}</ref> In July, it began construction on the first of its new 100-ton open-hearth furnaces.<ref>{{cite news|title=Job Situation Held Improved|work=The Cleveland Press|date=July 3, 1925|page=6}}</ref><ref name=addingnewstuff>{{cite news|title=Adding New Furnace|work=The Plain Dealer|date=July 4, 1925|page=6}}</ref> The company also purchased two 125-ton rail cars to handle larger amounts of molten steel,<ref name=addingnewstuff /><ref name=outputahead>{{cite news|title=Steel Output Ahead of 1924|work=The Cleveland Press|date=July 8, 1925|page=12}}</ref> installed new heating furnaces in its tin mills,<ref name=addingnewstuff /> and began experimenting with a new type of furnace in its rolling mills.<ref name=outputahead />
At the end of 1924,<ref name=25savings>{{cite news|title=O.K.'s New Coal Fueling System|work=The Plain Dealer|date=January 18, 1925|page=40}}</ref> Trumbull Steel began using pulverized coal as a fuel for all of its mill and annealing furnaces.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pulverized Coal at Trumbull Steel Mills|work=The Iron Age|date=March 26, 1925|accessdate=January 16, 2026|page=885|url=https://archive.org/details/sim_chiltons-iron-age_1925-03-26_115_13/mode/2up?q=%22Trumbull+Steel%22}}</ref> The firm said it would save 25% a year on fuel costs.<ref name=25savings /> In February 1925, the company began installing new boilers and upgrading all its piping<ref>{{cite news|title=Trumbull Improvements|work=The Cleveland Press|date=February 10, 1925|page=14}}</ref> and its common stock began trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]'s [[Curb trading|curb market]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Notes From Exchanges|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=February 17, 1925|page=18}}</ref> In July, it began construction on the first of its new 100-ton open-hearth furnaces.<ref>{{cite news|title=Job Situation Held Improved|work=The Cleveland Press|date=July 3, 1925|page=6}}</ref><ref name=addingnewstuff>{{cite news|title=Adding New Furnace|work=The Plain Dealer|date=July 4, 1925|page=6}}</ref> The company also purchased two 125-ton rail cars to handle larger amounts of molten steel,<ref name=addingnewstuff /><ref name=outputahead>{{cite news|title=Steel Output Ahead of 1924|work=The Cleveland Press|date=July 8, 1925|page=12}}</ref> installed new heating furnaces in its tin mills,<ref name=addingnewstuff /> and began experimenting with a new type of furnace in its rolling mills.<ref name=outputahead />

The season is scheduled to begin with two downhills at [[St. Moritz]], Switzerland on 12 and 13 December 2025 and then to remain in Europe all season, according to the initial schedule released on 12 June 2025.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://assets.fis-ski.com/f/252177/x/6a75c512ed/2526_men_08-05-2025_website.pdf|title=Audi FIS Ski Women's World Cup 2025/26 Initial Schedule|website=fis-ski.com|date=12 June 1015|access-date=1 July 2025}}</ref> For the first time since [[2010–11 FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|2011]], the Di Prampero course in [[Tarvisio]], Italy will host the World Cup circuit on 17 January 2026; most recently, the course hosted the [[World Junior Alpine Skiing Championships 2025|2025 FIS Junior World Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://intrieste.com/2025/06/14/tarvisio-to-host-2026-womens-world-cup-ski-races-boosting-italys-alpine-prestige/|title=Tarvisio to Host 2026 Women's World Cup Ski Races, Boosting Italy's Alpine Prestige|website=italia.it|date=14 June 2025|access-date=1 July 2025}}</ref>
The season is scheduled to begin with two downhills at [[St. Moritz]], Switzerland on 12 and 13 December 2025 and then to remain in Europe all season, according to the initial schedule released on 12 June 2025.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://assets.fis-ski.com/f/252177/x/6a75c512ed/2526_men_08-05-2025_website.pdf|title=Audi FIS Ski Women's World Cup 2025/26 Initial Schedule|website=fis-ski.com|date=12 June 1015|access-date=1 July 2025}}</ref> For the first time since [[2010–11 FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|2011]], the Di Prampero course in [[Tarvisio]], Italy will host the World Cup circuit on 17 January 2026; most recently, the course hosted the [[World Junior Alpine Skiing Championships 2025|2025 FIS Junior World Championships]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://intrieste.com/2025/06/14/tarvisio-to-host-2026-womens-world-cup-ski-races-boosting-italys-alpine-prestige/|title=Tarvisio to Host 2026 Women's World Cup Ski Races, Boosting Italy's Alpine Prestige|website=italia.it|date=14 June 2025|access-date=1 July 2025}}</ref>


The season will be interrupted for the quadrennial [[Alpine skiing at the 2026 Winter Olympics|2026 Winter Olympics]] in three regions in Italy -- [[Milan]], the [[Stelvio Pass]], and [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]]—during 6–22 February 2026.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://milanocortina2026.olympics.com/en|title=Winter Olympic Games: Milano Cortina 2026|accessdate=1 July 2025}}</ref> The Alpine speed skiing events for women are scheduled to take place on the classic [[Olimpia delle Tofane]] course at [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://milanocortina2026.olympics.com/en/bormio|title=Milano Cortina 2026: Bormio|accessdate=1 July 2025}}</ref> The championship in women's downhill is scheduled to be held on Sunday, 8 February.
The season will be interrupted for the quadrennial [[Alpine skiing at the 2026 Winter Olympics|2026 Winter Olympics]] in three regions in Italy{{snd}}[[Milan]], the [[Stelvio Pass]], and [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]]{{snd}}during 6–22 February 2026.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://milanocortina2026.olympics.com/en|title=Winter Olympic Games: Milano Cortina 2026|accessdate=1 July 2025}}</ref> The Alpine speed skiing events for women are scheduled to take place on the classic [[Olimpia delle Tofane]] course at [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://milanocortina2026.olympics.com/en/bormio|title=Milano Cortina 2026: Bormio|accessdate=1 July 2025}}</ref> The championship in women's downhill is scheduled to be held on Sunday, 8 February.

Line 21: Line 21:
==Articulation==
==Articulation==
Back vowels vary in [[vowel height]] (e.g. close {{IPA|[u]}} vs. open {{IPA|[ɑ]}}) and in lip rounding. They can also differ in degree of tongue-body retraction (e.g. fully back vs. near-back). Intermediate values can be indicated with IPA diacritics for relative advancement/retraction ({{angbr IPA|u̟}}, {{angbr IPA|u̠}}) and centralization ({{angbr IPA|ü}}).<ref name="IPAHandbook11-13" />
Back vowels vary in [[vowel height]] (e.g. close {{IPA|[u]}} vs. open {{IPA|[ɑ]}}) and in lip rounding. They can also differ in degree of tongue-body retraction (e.g. fully back vs. near-back). Intermediate values can be indicated with IPA diacritics for relative advancement/retraction ({{angbr IPA|u̟}}, {{angbr IPA|u̠}}) and centralization ({{angbr IPA|ü}}).<ref name="IPAHandbook11-13" />

Some phonetic descriptions further distinguish types of rounding (e.g. protrusion vs. labial compression).<ref name="LadefogedMaddieson1990">{{Cite journal |last1=Ladefoged |first1=Peter |last2=Maddieson |first2=Ian |title=Vowels of the world's languages |journal=Journal of Phonetics |year=1990 |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=93–122 |doi=10.1016/S0095-4470(19)30396-1}}</ref>
Some phonetic descriptions further distinguish types of rounding (e.g. protrusion vs. labial compression).<ref name="LadefogedMaddieson1990">{{Cite journal |last1=Ladefoged |first1=Peter |last2=Maddieson |first2=Ian |title=Vowels of the world's languages |journal=Journal of Phonetics |year=1990 |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=93–122 |doi=10.1016/S0095-4470(19)30396-1}}</ref>

source_payload.html:
Albanian–Yugoslav tensions

← Previous revision Revision as of 17:00, 8 February 2026
Line 116: Line 116:
===Albanian–Yugoslav tensions===
===Albanian–Yugoslav tensions===


Until [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]'s expulsion from the [[Cominform]] in 1948, Albania was effectively a Yugoslav satellite. {{citation needed|date=November 2025}} In repudiating the 1943 Albanian internal [[Mukaj agreement]] under pressure from the Yugoslavs, Albania's communists had given up on their demands for a Yugoslav cession of [[Kosovo]] to Albania after the war. In January 1945, the two governments signed a treaty establishing Kosovo as a Yugoslav autonomous province. Shortly thereafter, Yugoslavia became the first country to recognize Albania's provisional government.
Until [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]'s expulsion from the [[Cominform]] in 1948, Albania was effectively a Yugoslav satellite.{{citation needed|date=November 2025}} In repudiating the 1943 Albanian internal [[Mukaj agreement]] under pressure from the Yugoslavs, Albania's communists had given up on their demands for a Yugoslav cession of [[Kosovo]] to Albania after the war. In January 1945, the two governments signed a treaty establishing Kosovo as a Yugoslav autonomous province. Shortly thereafter, Yugoslavia became the first country to recognize Albania's provisional government.


In July 1946, Yugoslavia and Albania signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation that was quickly followed by a series of technical and economic agreements laying the groundwork for integrating the Albanian and Yugoslav economies. The pacts provided for coordinating the economic plans of both states, standardizing their monetary systems, and creating a common pricing system and a customs union. So close was the Yugoslav-Albanian relationship that [[Serbo-Croatian]] became a required subject in Albanian high schools.{{cn|date=August 2024}}
In July 1946, Yugoslavia and Albania signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation that was quickly followed by a series of technical and economic agreements laying the groundwork for integrating the Albanian and Yugoslav economies. The pacts provided for coordinating the economic plans of both states, standardizing their monetary systems, and creating a common pricing system and a customs union. So close was the Yugoslav-Albanian relationship that [[Serbo-Croatian]] became a required subject in Albanian high schools.{{cn|date=August 2024}}

|url-status=live}}</ref> It is inspired by the 1990 novel ''[[Vineland]]'' by [[Thomas Pynchon]].<ref name="WGA 2025">{{cite web |title=One Battle After Another |publisher=[[Writers Guild of America]] |url=https://directories.wga.org/project/1265934/one-battle-after-another/ |access-date=September 2, 2025 [[ensemble cast]] is led by [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Sean Penn]], [[Benicio del Toro]], [[Regina Hall]], [[Teyana Taylor]], and [[Chase Infiniti]] (in her film debut). The story follows an ex-revolutionary who is forced back into his former combative lifestyle when he and his daughter are pursued by a corrupt military officer.

v2.05 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - (You can help) - Alexander Nisbet

← Previous revision Revision as of 17:00, 8 February 2026
Line 38: Line 38:
===17th century and Civil War===
===17th century and Civil War===


Alexander Nesbit was a royalist who was devoted to [[Charles I of England]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nesbit was appointed sheriff of Berwickshire, however when the king's policies led to military confrontation with his Scottish and English subjects, Nesbit and his sons joined the king's standard at [[Oxford]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nesbit's eldest son, Philip, was abroad when the civil war broke out but when he returned he was knighted and given command of a regiment.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Philip Nesbit was lieutenant governor of [[Newark-on-Trent]] during the [[Relief of Newark|Siege of Newark]] that was carried out by [[David Leslie, Lord Newark|General David Leslie, Lord Newark]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> When Nesbit left Newark he became an officer for [[James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Montrose was surprised by a strong force of [[Covenanter]] cavalry at the [[Battle of Philiphaugh]] where Philip Nesbit was captured.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> He was then executed at [[Glasgow]] on 28 October 1646.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Two of Philip's brothers, Alexander and Robert, were also killed during the [[Scotland in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms|Scottish Civil War]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> The youngest brother, Adam, survived and he was the father of the heraldic writer, [[Alexander Nisbet]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/>
Alexander Nesbit was a royalist who was devoted to [[Charles I of England]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nesbit was appointed sheriff of Berwickshire, however when the king's policies led to military confrontation with his Scottish and English subjects, Nesbit and his sons joined the king's standard at [[Oxford]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nesbit's eldest son, Philip, was abroad when the civil war broke out but when he returned he was knighted and given command of a regiment.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Philip Nesbit was lieutenant governor of [[Newark-on-Trent]] during the [[Relief of Newark|Siege of Newark]] that was carried out by [[David Leslie, Lord Newark|General David Leslie, Lord Newark]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> When Nesbit left Newark he became an officer for [[James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Montrose was surprised by a strong force of [[Covenanter]] cavalry at the [[Battle of Philiphaugh]] where Philip Nesbit was captured.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> He was then executed at [[Glasgow]] on 28 October 1646.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Two of Philip's brothers, Alexander and Robert, were also killed during the [[Scotland in the Wars of the Three Kingdoms|Scottish Civil War]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> The youngest brother, Adam, survived and he was the father of the heraldic writer, [[Alexander Nisbet (antiquarian)|Alexander Nisbet]].<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/>


===18th and 19th centuries===
===18th and 19th centuries===
[[File:Nisbetmemorial.jpg|thumb|Nisbet memorial]]
[[File:Nisbetmemorial.jpg|thumb|Nisbet memorial]]
[[Alexander Nisbet]] initially trained as a lawyer but soon acquired a passion for history and heraldry.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> In 1702 he published his first work, an essay on cadency.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> His great work was ''System of Heraldry'' which was published in 1722 with more editions following in 1742, 1804 and 1816.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nisbet died in 1725.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/>
[[Alexander Nisbet (antiquarian)|Alexander Nisbet]] initially trained as a lawyer but soon acquired a passion for history and heraldry.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> In 1702 he published his first work, an essay on cadency.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> His great work was ''System of Heraldry'' which was published in 1722 with more editions following in 1742, 1804 and 1816.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/> Nisbet died in 1725.<ref name="Clan.Encyclopedia.Nesbitt"/>
